This is the Dragon contending with the Tiger in battle—water surging, fire erupting, the cauldron seething and boiling over, their forces overturned and restrained, at times emitting the cries of an infant. The Yellow Dame and Elder Ding lend their numinous might; the True Man of Stone says: *"The Yellow Dame’s twin breasts are fair, Elder Ding’s heart is kind and merciful. Dragon and Tiger wage their war—how could the bound lord ever know?"* The Yellow Dame was explained earlier; Elder Ding is the gentle fire.

Master Yin the True says: *"I hold the Dao of the world, endless and boundless—yet I know only how to subdue the infant’s heart."* This is the true revelation of heaven’s secret. The shaking of heaven and earth startles gods and ghosts. An ancient song says: *"The sage seizes the workings of creation, grasps sun and moon to place within the furnace. Gently stirring the essence of heaven and earth, he gathers yin and yang to rouse gods and ghosts."* Gods and ghosts are the celestial soul and earthly spirit.

In an instant, the battle ceases and the clouds disperse—clouds gather and rain scatters, all sounds return to silence, and within the palm, fortune is transformed. A mysterious pearl is planted in the mud’s depths. The *Fuming Pian* says: *"At night, chaos falls to the earth—all the ten thousand images and signs know nothing of it."* This is the single drop descending into the Yellow Court. The Yellow Court is the central palace, the Yellow Chamber, the Mysterious Pass—likened to the mud’s depths.

Master Ziyang says: *"Within one double-hour, the elixir is complete—this is the elixir’s daily accomplishment."* Day by day, it grows by a grain of millet, gradually forming the mysterious pearl. The Yellow Emperor sought the mysterious pearl in the Red Waters—without the formless one, none could obtain it. This is that pearl; the formless one is without thought or care. From this, the root and sprout gradually mature. Constantly irrigated, it embraces true essence. Master Sanguzi says: *"Establish the foundation for a hundred days, nurture it through the full cycle of stars. Simply guard the essence, tone, and spirit—water will naturally moisten, fire will naturally nurture, awaiting the qi’s fullness."*

After ten months, the embryo is shed, and it is swallowed into the belly—suddenly, one senses the mortal body already imbued with spirit. Master Ziyang also says: *"A single grain of numinous elixir is swallowed into the belly."* He speaks of *shedding the embryo* and *communing with the divine and sagely*. The *Cantong Qi* says: *"Golden sand enters the five viscera, mist scatters like wind and rain."* If this is the inner elixir, why does it speak of entering the belly, the mouth, the five viscera? Later generations doubted this and took it for an external elixir. Little did they know that *form arises from the formless*—this is what is called the Returned Elixir.

True Master Unity speaks of first exploring the primal chaotic qi of heaven and earth to establish the root; then taking the essence of Qian and Kun, subtly moving its traces to form the model; following the numbers of Kan, Li, Pi, and Tai to determine punishment and virtue; stealing the mechanism of yin-yang’s transformations to complete winter and summer. Yin is born after noon, yang arises at midnight’s start—thus Qian and Kun serve as the crucible and vessel, Kan and Li as the medicinal substances, the remaining sixty hexagrams as the fire times. Refining, nurturing, and subtly seizing the work of transformation—like fruit growing on a branch, the child within the womb, after ten months of fire times and qi’s fullness, suddenly sheds its spirit to enter the true embryo, uniting with heaven.

Thus it speaks of entering the mouth, the belly, the five viscera. The *Cantong Qi* says: *"It resembles a chicken’s egg, white and black aligned, a single inch in length and breadth, as the beginning. The four limbs, five viscera, sinews, and bones are all complete. After ten months, it emerges from the womb."* This is *form arising from the formless*, a body beyond the body. Clinging to the old frame traps one in darkness; emerging from the ninth mud allows roaming heaven and earth. One’s name is inscribed in the immortal register, one’s title is True Man—this is the time when the great man’s work is accomplished and his name established.

This matter is rare in the world, not something ordinary people can know. If one lacks the immortal bones of past lives, how could one easily encounter it? Having encountered it, one should swiftly refine it—time flies like an arrow. To catch the fish, one must cast the net; do not stand by the abyss and sigh in vain. I hear you have known the medicine for many years—why not gather your heart and refine mercury and lead? Do not let the candle be blown out by the wind, for the six paths of rebirth leave no room for complaint.

These words admonish Immortal Liu, urging him to gather his heart and refine mercury and lead. From this, it is clear that the inner elixir must be refined within oneself—it is not a matter of external medicine. Recently, worldly people have grown cunning, competing to don Daoist robes and claim the Way. Ask them what metal and wood are—they fall silent, mute and ashamed.

Metal and wood are explained in the *Essential Pointers*: *"Without knowing this, one cannot speak of the Returned Elixir."* Yet they speak of breath cultivation and fasting, claiming other schools and doctrines are profound. Have you not seen the *Song of Breaking Delusion*? *"The Great One embraces true qi—this method is strongest."* The myriad minor side paths, though countless, have nothing to do with the Way of Golden Liquor and the Returned Inner Elixir. What is called the Dao? The Great One embracing true qi, the five stars aligning in a string, the sun and moon conjoining—this is how the inner elixir is formed, how the Dharma-body emerges. There is no second gate.

Do not fault my words for their crudeness—it is only because the world lacks discernment. Only when your heart aligns with mine will I dare pour out my thoughts for you.

---

**Regulating the Center Diagram**
*Preface to the Twelve-Character Formula of the Regulating the Center Diagram*

Three thousand six hundred methods, dozens of schools for nurturing life—all are side paths, nothing but crooked trails. Take, for example, breath cultivation to inflate the empty belly, the *Elbow-Behind Flying Golden Essence*, absorbing and grinding to move the river chariot, holding the breath as fire times, inhaling the clear and exhaling the turbid, connecting to realms and lamenting flows, guiding the turtle and turning the perch, mirroring forms to seek liberation, storing the chimney, guarding the brow’s center—all are adding heads atop heads, stirring trouble where there is none, overturning order and deviating from the utmost truth.

Thus, the hundred vessels boil over, the three fields collapse into chaos. What was meant to grant eternal life instead harms it. This is truly going against the harmony of heaven and earth, failing to align with nature’s intent. After simplifying and studying the *Cantong Qi* for thirty years, I have grasped its mysteries. Drawing from the threads of the alchemical classics, I composed the *Twelve-Character Formula of the Regulating the Center Diagram* to transmit to those who study the Dao. It takes rectifying the heart and sincerely cultivating intention as its foundation, the central pillar—abiding in the center to govern the external.

With the eight characters as auxiliaries, one regulates and governs the four seasons, responding to the internal from the external. Above, it aligns with the heart of heaven; in the middle, it examines human affairs; silently, it accords with creation, following the course of yin and yang. Externally, it models the five phases; internally, it orders the five viscera—thus forming the endless cycle of daily use.

It does not rely on action, nor does it depend on visualization. Serenely, in great stillness, it unites the primal mechanism. One must only sever cravings, stabilize the heart and qi, reduce thoughts, moderate diet, regulate breath, guard against drowsiness, and restrain the senses—nurturing the harmony of heaven. Within the four dignified postures, one merges with nature, without any complexity or difficulty.

For those who have already established the *yinqie* (the alchemical crucible), this serves to harmonize with the firing process and nurture the sacred embryo. For those who have not yet established the *yinqie*, this strengthens the primal qi, nourishes the spirit, and serves as the gradual foundation for its establishment. As for depletion, loss, illness, and affliction, this method dispels sickness, fortifies the primal, and serves as the art of supplementation, longevity, and life-nurturing—truly the gateway of simplicity!

**The Regulating the Center Diagram**
To "regulate the center" is to dwell within a compass, neither in the middle nor within or without—neither clinging to images nor attaching to things. It resides in the center of the body, the center of intention, like the self within a great mirror. Simply rectify the heart and sincerely cultivate intention as the central pillar. When all distractions vanish, the true person appears—like a fish in the deep abyss, swimming freely yet never leaving the square inch. This is the true person abiding in the profound depths, floating and guarding the regulated center.

When joy, anger, sorrow, and delight have yet to arise, at this moment, one may reside in the regulated center, floating and swimming while subtly governing the four seasons to rectify creation. Within the four dignified postures, one must not lose proper measure! When things come, respond and then pass, returning to the center—never disturbing the central pillar. Within the center, always maintain emptiness, not a speck of dust standing. Over time, neither indulgent nor restrained, one naturally attains its benefits.

Its essential subtlety lies in the six yin returning to *Kun*, all things reverting to the origin, the *Fu* hexagram’s first sprouting. The eldest son succeeds the father’s body; where the solitary yang stirs in concealment, before the myriad things are born—all arises from this point, the place of activation.

At this time, sit cross-legged in great stillness, concentrate the spirit within, and regulate the breath to be continuous. Silently guard it, and a single qi emerges from the formless void—dim and obscure, without color or shape, manifesting in the profound darkness of *Kun* and *Gui*, born within the kidneys to nurture the primal essence, replenish and sustain the primal qi, ceaselessly strengthening day by day. First, it dispels illness; next, it returns to infancy. Accumulated, it becomes the foundation of the inner elixir!

Master Tuzhen said: "This is the primal qi replenishing the primal qi—how could it be mere common cinnabar?" This is the supreme method of supplementation.

**Morning Layering (Zhaotun)**
The *Zhaotun* embodies the beginning of the noble one’s governance, the first sprouting of the myriad things—the inception of benevolence. At the *zi* hour, the qi of initial generation resides in the kidneys. It comes unbidden, and one should treasure and nurture it. Regulate the breath so the ears do not hear it; simply listen to its gentle, continuous flow, harmonizing with nature, resonating with the key of heaven and earth. Over time, kidney qi merges with heart qi, the two qi interacting to descend sweet dew and produce the mysterious pearl!

**Evening Enveloping (Mumeng)**
"Enveloping to nurture correctness" is the sagely work, not losing the heart of the infant. At the *wu* hour, the qi of initial generation resides in the heart. Without thought or worry, in utter stillness, inwardly illuminate and unite with it. One should sit in quietude to gather it. Over time, heart qi naturally merges with kidney qi, accomplishing the work of *jiji* (completion and benefit).

Humans reside within the three powers, their body equaling heaven and earth, thus corresponding to the qi of heaven and earth and aligning with the essence of the true one. A person’s primal qi spans eight hundred and ten *zhang*, resembling the bellows and key. Thus, the great movement of primal qi follows heaven, and the lesser movement follows the sun. Yet people cannot embody and emulate heaven and earth, leading to rupture, damage, and the scattering of spirit—deviating from them on their own. How could heaven and earth deviate from them?

If one can follow its principles and grasp its mechanism, one may accord with the work of creation and engage in elixir refinement—the inner cultivation of the Dao of long life and enduring vision. Beyond humans, all are endowed with turbid confusion within the primal qi, merely transformed things. How could they govern the primal qi?

The *Cantong Qi* states:
"In spring and summer, rely on the inner body, from *zi* to *chen-si*;
In autumn and winter, employ the outer use, from *wu* to *xu-hai*."

It also says:
"Rewards and punishments correspond to spring and autumn;
Dusk and dawn follow cold and heat.
The line statements hold benevolence and righteousness,
Timely expressing joy and anger.
Thus responding to the four seasons,
The five phases attain their principles."

Therefore, *zi-chou-yin* correspond to spring, *mao-chen-si* to summer, *wu-wei-shen* to autumn, and *you-xu-hai* to winter.

*Zi-chou-yin* align with spring, when wood governs—wood embodies benevolence, the time of the myriad things’ arising. Thus, the two characters *xihe* (radiant harmony) nurture it, flourishing like spring ascending a terrace. *He* (harmony) is beauty—central yellow penetrating principle, rightly positioned in the body, flowing through the four limbs, manifesting in undertakings, the utmost beauty. Like an infant not yet laughing, crying without hoarseness—this is the utmost harmony. Unaware of the union of male and female, yet the genitalia stir—this is the utmost essence.

*Mao-chen-si* align with summer, when fire governs—fire embodies ritual, the time of the myriad things’ flourishing. Thus, the two characters *zhonghe* (central harmony) nurture it. Once harmonized, without excess or deficiency, this is called the center, where emotions and nature roam freely without turbulence.

*Wu-wei-shen* align with autumn, when metal governs—metal embodies righteousness, the time of yellowing grass and falling leaves, the harvest of the myriad things. Thus, the two characters *lianjing* (gathering and stillness) nurture it, fulfilling the nature of the myriad things.

**Preface by Yuxi the Late Learner of Yichun, during the Purification Festival of the Bingyin year of the Xianchun era**

**Lyrics for the Qin Garden Offering**

Lifting the topic at hand is itself the affair of the Dao-heart.
Hark!
On a fine night of clear brightness,
In the primordial chaos of the infant child,
One attains the delight within the stringless zither—
The notes and tones are not for outsiders to know.

Sevenfold return of the elixir, gold reverts to its original nature:
This is the sevenfold return, achieving success through earth,
Called the ninefold return.
When emotion merges with the sea of nature, it is called union;
The furnace refines golden radiance, termed the return.
Nurtured wholly by the power of true earth,
The refined spiritual essence emerges from the dusty world.

For the practitioner, the great Dao resides solely within the self;
The inner elixir must be refined a hundred times.
The Great One divides into three, yet one is obtained;
The great medicine is sought only within the body.
Pitiful are the myriad thousands who take it all for pleasure and ease.

First, refine the self and await the moment.
Refining the self begins with subduing the heart;
Gathering the medicine has its own season.
Turning the mechanism sets one apart from the vulgar;
The heart is serene and still, like an infant.
Observe closely: the Creator originally has no thing—
When spring arrives in Jiangnan, flowers bloom of themselves.

At the first stirring of the true yang,
Kun transforms into Fu—
Is this not the heart of heaven and earth revealed?
Sitting in stillness upon the rush mat, thoughts cease;
The spirit’s abode breathes in and out, gradually slowing.
Warm, misty qi returns to the celestial valley—
Know this as the time when the one yang returns.

In the depths of night, the water clock endures:
The depths of night are midnight,
When within the clepsydra one first senses the lengthening hours.
Vapor rises in waves, all sounds are clear;
Within the body, the winter solstice arrives at the third watch.
Who can fathom such delightful savor?
Only the sound of the bronze clepsydra’s dripping is heard.

The lead cauldron, warm and gentle—
The cauldron is not of metal, the furnace not of the moon.
Li arises from below Kan, Dui resides within the cauldron.
The jade hare’s decoction boils and surges;
The golden furnace’s fire blazes, its light resplendent.
Who in the profound darkness recognizes the existence within nothingness?
Within lies golden radiance, the foundation of the sage.

Light pierces the curtains—
The original spirit generates yang;
The spirit’s light flickers, the heart illumines inwardly,
All returns to the primal void.
At first, the azure qi—color yet not color—
Emerges from the dragon tower to return to the phoenix palace.
Beneath the lapis lazuli screen, candles glow in mutual brilliance;
By the Jiang’s head, the rain has just ceased.

Creation hastens swiftly:
Husband and wife return to the chamber.
When the moon reaches the yang palace,
Amidst the peach-blossom waves,
Dragon and tiger meet.
Red and black converge, unknown to the world;
All relies on Wu and Ji as the matchmaker.
A full ladle of the marrow of heaven and earth—
Seek it with intent and sip it in.

The work of advancing the fire is like navigating peril.
Fire arises within water, flowers bloom within thunder;
One must remain vigilant, applying skillful means with stability.
Within the realm of primordial chaos, qi is misty and warm;
On the branch of red apricot, it is the second month of spring.
Simply secure the golden gate firmly shut—
The turning mechanism is ever the treasure within the house.

By the winding river, the moon’s radiance is serene and bright—
A crow takes flight.
The oxherd and weaver girl share affection;
The Dao is fundamentally like the tortoise and snake,
Innately so.
When the yang crow meets the new moon, they unite in beauty;
The two qi mutually support and revolve.
This is the mutual affinity of lead and mercury—
Do not mistake it for the nine bends of the small intestine.

Master Xiaozhen’s verse says:
Above the winding river, the magpie bridge spans;
The oxherd and weaver girl’s bond—
This is the Dao itself.
The great medicine, the golden elixir, is born from this.
If you do not believe, knock upon the gate of Jia and Yi—
The twin youths will naturally guide you on your way.
The gate of Jia and Yi is like the gate of Wu and Ji.
This principle is profoundly deep and far-reaching,
Difficult to express with brush or tongue—
Yet it is merely the affair of the body itself.

Hark!
To know the path beneath the mountain,
Ask those who come and go.

At that time, one drinks the knife and measure:
The two earths are Wu and Ji;
The golden blade is lead and mercury.
Dragon coiled, tiger crouched, they guard the center;
Li and Kan unite, the light of sun and moon.
After drinking, one awakens and returns to the grotto palace—
In the flowery pond, the lotus fragrance is rich.

Who would believe a child is nurtured within nothingness?
Within the body, yin and yang;
Within the pot, sun and moon.
All immortals and sages—
Originally, there is no difference.
If one is not of this realm,
How can I explain it?

Refine essence to nurture the spiritual root, refine qi to nurture the spirit;
The merging of lead and mercury gestates the true body.
Suddenly, one emerges through the crown of the mud-pill palace—
Only then does one trust that the immortals do not deceive.

Discern the clarity and turbidity of the water’s source,
The separation of wood and metal—
Without a teacher’s guidance,
This matter is difficult to know.
Lead sinks, silver floats;
The clear is above, the turbid below.
The clear is golden radiance, the turbid is leaden essence.
To merge golden radiance with the liquid of wood—
This is the wondrous method of employing lead.
When the two substances meet, emotion and nature blend;
When the millet pearl forms, wood and metal separate.
Without a teacher’s guidance,
This matter is difficult to know.
Clear and turbid, sinking and floating, share a single source;
To take the clear and discard the turbid is even more profound.
The blending and separation must be distinguished—
The wonder lies in a single word from a true teacher.

The Dao is subtle and mysterious, the heavenly mechanism deep and distant;
To begin practice swiftly is still too late.
Only when one reaches the point of shame in learning
Does one realize one’s skill is not refined.

As Master Baiyun said:
Those who slander it are like grasping a giant melon stem to sweep Kunlun;
Those who taste it are like swans drinking from the vast sea.
The views of the well-frog and fence-sparrow—
How could they know the vastness of sea and sky?

Diligence without encounter—
One must eventually encounter it;
To encounter it and not refine it is utter folly.
Cherish each moment, do not let time pass in vain.
One must awaken swiftly and practice urgently—
When will the precious pearl in hand become bright?
If the hut is ruined, how can it be rebuilt?

Within the millet pearl, the world is vast;
The immortals and perfected ones enter it with vigor.
How many gaze in vain, merely admiring—
Sighing in vain that the heavens are high and unattainable.

Master Changchun’s verse says:
Sun and moon swiftly fly above the crown;
Time swiftly passes before the eyes.
Turning to look back, one is already old—
To begin practice swiftly is still too late.

During the Shaoxing era, in the southern part of Yichun City, the household of Prefect Wei was often shrouded in mystery. One day, a strange man entered directly into the study and called out, "Prefect Wei, come and speak with me." At that time, Wei was napping during the day, and his attendants dared not inform him. The stranger then inscribed a *ci* poem on the wall before leaving, titled *Sumuzhe*. When Wei awoke and saw it, he deeply regretted it, sending people to search for the man, but he could not be found. The poem read:

Gold surges through the waters, aligning with the Dipper;
Jade locks and golden gates—
Guardian spirits stand watch.
Crimson waters, cinnabar terraces,
Dragons and tigers roam,
Myriad forms in solemn array,
Vigorously casting forth the pearl.

Drink from the sacred spring, refine the fire’s timing,
The Great One’s furnace opens,
The elixir ripens, divine radiance shines through.
Fleeting fame and profit soon fade—
Begin practice swiftly,
Seek the existence within nothingness.
The path to Penglai—
Rely on three thousand deeds fulfilled,
Striding alone upon the clouds to return.

The *Scripture of the August Void* states: "Those who wish to cultivate the Dao must first establish merit. Thus, the Celestial Emperors, the exalted Lords of Heaven, the Perfected Ones, and the Divine Immortals all ascend to the sacred and true ranks through meritorious effort. Heaven records merit, and those in the world who cultivate the true and sincere resolve—once merit is complete and virtue perfected—shed their mortal forms to become immortals, immortals transform into Perfected Ones, and Perfected Ones attain boundless freedom, merging with the natural. When dissolved, they become qi; when at rest, they become human. With divine powers unrestrained, they transform without form, soaring through the Three Realms, traversing the hidden and obscure. Those who practice refinement must first cherish essence and treasure qi, anchoring the mind and concentrating spirit to establish the foundation of nurturing. Then, entering seclusion for three thousand days, internal work must not be lacking, until the embryo is fully formed, transcending to the primordial origin. External conduct also aids this, aligning with the Dao of Heaven. Thus, merit is never too much, and deeds are never too vast. With three thousand merits fulfilled, one becomes an immortal in the Great Veil; with three thousand deeds accomplished, one becomes a guest in the Great Veil."

Master Zhongli said: "Merit without conduct is like having no feet; conduct without merit leaves one unable to advance. Only with both merit and conduct complete are the feet fully prepared—who then can say one has no share in becoming a divine immortal?"

Moreover, in cultivating the Dao and attaining the Way, one first resides in Penglai, Fangzhang, or Yingzhou, becoming a free-roaming immortal. The Supreme One, the Primordial Lord, then summons one to receive the chart, inscribing one’s name in the immortal register, ascending step by step to the sacred rank, paying homage to the Jade Emperor, and bearing the title of Perfected One. One must further guide and enlighten those who come after, spreading teachings and transformations, until reaching the state of no cultivation and no attainment—this is called the natural.

A poem by a High Perfected One reads:
In the tenth month, the fire’s timing is cast aside,
Internal work is counted in three thousand days.
Further relying on external conduct to align with the Dao of Heaven,
Transcending to the primordial origin, one attains the rank of Supreme Immortal.

On the day when Master Quanzhen, Wa Zhang, attained the Dao, he composed the *Ci of Untying the Pendant*, saying:
Cultivators of the Way,
Your meritorious efforts are no small matter.
Discern the reversal and inversion of the Five Phases,
The wondrous principle is profoundly abstruse.
Within the jade furnace, dragons coil and tigers crouch,
In the golden tripod, the supreme treasure is refined.
The yang spirit departs the body,
Vast and obscure,
In an instant, it roams the Three Isles.
Once entry and exit are mastered,
Restrain and hold fast,
Seek further mysteries,
Merge with true emptiness—
The Great Void is the ultimate end.

Five Secret Poems:

**I**
Hiss and exhale—three feet, yet no trace,
Released and gathered swiftly as the wind.
Among a hundred thousand, select one or two,
This Dao is entrusted to you alone.

**II**
Extended like lightning, round as the moon,
Not for men—do not draw near.
To realize Buddhahood or become a Perfected One,
These subtle wonders require a master.

**III**
Severing nails and cutting iron, dispelling delusion,
The wondrous use, freely applied, comes from the master.
Returning at will, filling the sleeves,
Cherish and nurture it like a grandson.

**IV**
Radiance blazes, pressing upon the body,
Bones tremble, hairs stand on end—what is to be done?
If you are truly a man, you will not fear,
With a single flourish, the truth is revealed at once.

**V**
Among a hundred thousand, one or two,
A single flourish must align with the hearts of sages and worthies.
The Red Youth manifests divine auspices,
Withered wood blooms, iron turns to gold.

**Eulogy for the Portrait of the Pure Yang Immortal**
Supreme virtue defies description,
Primordial merit governs nothing—
What need for verses or praises?
Heaven is impartial,
Only virtue is aided;
The sagely teacher is never far.

With the bearing of a phoenix and the essence of a dragon,
A true Confucian of his generation,
His beard like a coiled dragon, his moon-like visage—
A descendant of Tang officials.
Awakened by the dream of yellow millet,
He severed the endless cycle of life and death.
Once the elixir was complete, he sought only to deliver others,
His rank exalted, ever aiding the drowning.
In the south, he refined gold lead and wood mercury;
In Bianjing, he tasted jade nectar and *suka*.
Spreading the One Vibration to perfect the true,
Countless living beings relied on his grace.
Wielding the Three Swords as admonitions,
Dark and countless disciples received his love.
At times, he wandered amidst white reeds and red dreams;
At times, he dwelled in the Purple Palace and Clear Capital.
Letting go of all, he beheld the Great Void,
Yet still stood in attendance in the Hall of Luminous Understanding.
Throughout the land, his noble demeanor was longed for,
His divine traces shone across the realm.

Master Guo on Mount Ao longed to return—
The master spoke of himself thus.
Daoist Peng still awaited enlightenment—
This was Peng Chongyang.

For eons, I have been foolish and deluded,
Entangled in habitual tendencies.
Since gaining discernment,
I have never measured my strength,
Indulging in every pursuit—
Only the Dao of immortals and Buddhas
Have I not yet inquired into.

My elder, Lord Yue Suchan of Changsha, a descendant of officials, shared my passion,
And we became friends despite the difference in age.
I knew he was a dharma-friend of Peng Chongyang and Hu Guchan,
All three having received the oral transmission of the Golden Elixir from Master Yuxi.
One day, as we spoke of the frontier,
He suddenly stood and spoke earnestly:
"In my daily visits to friends and searches for teachers,
I have spared neither body nor life.
Later, I met Master Yuxi,
And though you and I have only shared simple affections and casual discourse,
The time for learning the Dao has its own causes and conditions.
Since you have reached this point,
The time is now!
Wait for an auspicious day to transmit the teachings."
Thus, in the *chen* hour of the *jiazi* day,
He secretly imparted a few words,
Encouraging me to try them out.

Within less than a month, the elixir path proved efficacious—what was called "golden light suffusing the body," "jade towers and crimson palaces," "dragon and tiger, infant and maiden," all appearing in a fleeting trance with vivid clarity. Upon hearing this, Master Yue stroked his tears and sighed: "Since I first heard the Dao, my body has been plagued by fleshly ailments, preventing me from gathering my strength. Thus, I have yet to begin the work of stoking the fire. You, however, were born with immortal bones—this is no trifling matter. I dare not claim to be your teacher. Instead, I point to one among them who bears an uncanny resemblance to Master Yuxi. Simply don the robes and cap to capture the master’s likeness, and take him as your teacher. I now entrust you solemnly with all the master’s handwritten texts and these ten volumes."

Later, I heard from the slightly acquainted Administrator Shu Zong: "The master once stayed in my family’s home. When my father, the Pacification Commissioner, completed his term, we traveled together back to Huai, with the master lodging and dining in the kitchen boat, tethered by an iron chain to the stern of our vessel. As we neared Zhenzhou, a sudden storm arose, and the chain snapped—both boat and belongings vanished into the surging waves. Two days later, the master appeared at Yangzi Bridge, clutching a small bundle of clothes. As our boat was being woven together, he bid my father farewell in person before departing. Only then did we realize the master had attained the Dao of entering water without drowning. My family sighed in awe endlessly."

Since receiving the transmission, fifty-five years have passed, and now, at ninety, I have labored to depict the immortal’s likeness at the end of the preface to these ten volumes, committing them to woodblocks to ensure their wide dissemination. On this day of the fourteenth year of the Zhizheng era, Wang Junzhang of Zhongyang, with incense lit, respectfully inscribes this.

*Essential Pointers on the Elixir Classics of Master Yuxi, Volume the Lower* concludes.
